docs.title: metric_out
docs.description: the output metric file

docs.title: volume-to-surface-mapping
docs.description:
Map volume to surface.

You must specify exactly one mapping method.  Enclosing voxel uses the value from the voxel the vertex lies inside, while trilinear does a 3D linear interpolation based on the voxels immediately on each side of the vertex's position.

The ribbon mapping method constructs a polyhedron from the vertex's neighbors on each surface, and estimates the amount of this polyhedron's volume that falls inside any nearby voxels, to use as the weights for sampling.  If -thin-columns is specified, the polyhedron uses the edge midpoints and triangle centroids, so that neighboring vertices do not have overlapping polyhedra.  This may require increasing -voxel-subdiv to get enough samples in each voxel to reliably land inside these smaller polyhedra.  The volume ROI is useful to exclude partial volume effects of voxels the surfaces pass through, and will cause the mapping to ignore voxels that don't have a positive value in the mask.  The subdivision number specifies how it approximates the amount of the volume the polyhedron intersects, by splitting each voxel into NxNxN pieces, and checking whether the center of each piece is inside the polyhedron.  If you have very large voxels, consider increasing this if you get zeros in your output.  The -gaussian option makes it act more like the myelin method, where the distance of a voxel from <surface> is used to downweight the voxel.  The -interpolate suboption, instead of doing a weighted average of voxels, interpolates from the volume at the subdivided points inside the ribbon.  If using both -interpolate and the -weighted suboption to -volume-roi, the roi volume weights are linearly interpolated, unless the -interpolate method is ENCLOSING_VOXEL, in which case ENCLOSING_VOXEL is also used for sampling the roi volume weights.

The myelin style method uses part of the caret5 myelin mapping command to do the mapping: for each surface vertex, take all voxels that are in a cylinder with radius and height equal to cortical thickness, centered on the vertex and aligned with the surface normal, and that are also within the ribbon ROI, and apply a gaussian kernel with the specified sigma to them to get the weights to use.  The -legacy-bug flag reverts to the unintended behavior present from the initial implementation up to and including v1.2.3, which had only the tangential cutoff and a bounding box intended to be larger than where the cylinder cutoff should have been.

docs.title: volume
docs.description: the volume to map data from

docs.title: surface
docs.description: the surface to map the data onto

docs.title: metric_out
docs.description: the output metric file

docs.title: opt_trilinear
docs.description: use trilinear volume interpolation

docs.title: opt_enclosing
docs.description: use value of the enclosing voxel

docs.title: opt_cubic
docs.description: use cubic splines

docs.title: ribbon_constrained
docs.description: use ribbon constrained mapping algorithm

docs.title: inner_surf
docs.description: the inner surface of the ribbon

docs.title: outer_surf
docs.description: the outer surface of the ribbon

docs.title: volume_roi
docs.description: use a volume roi

docs.title: roi_volume
docs.description: the roi volume file

docs.title: opt_weighted
docs.description: treat the roi values as weightings rather than binary

docs.title: volume_roi
docs.description: use a volume roi

docs.title: opt_voxel_subdiv_subdiv_num
docs.description: voxel divisions while estimating voxel weights: number of subdivisions, default 3

docs.title: opt_thin_columns
docs.description: use non-overlapping polyhedra

docs.title: opt_gaussian_scale
docs.description: reduce weight to voxels that aren't near <surface>: value to multiply the local thickness by, to get the gaussian sigma

docs.title: opt_interpolate_method
docs.description: instead of a weighted average of voxels, interpolate at subpoints inside the ribbon: interpolation method, must be CUBIC, ENCLOSING_VOXEL, or TRILINEAR

docs.title: opt_bad_vertices_out_roi_out
docs.description: output an ROI of which vertices didn't intersect any valid voxels: the output metric file of vertices that have no data

docs.title: weights_out
docs.description: volume to write the weights to

docs.title: output_weights
docs.description: write the voxel weights for a vertex to a volume file

docs.title: vertex
docs.description: the vertex number to get the voxel weights for, 0-based

docs.title: weights_out
docs.description: volume to write the weights to

docs.title: output_weights
docs.description: write the voxel weights for a vertex to a volume file

docs.title: opt_output_weights_text_text_out
docs.description: write the voxel weights for all vertices to a text file: output - the output text filename

docs.title: ribbon_constrained
docs.description: use ribbon constrained mapping algorithm

docs.title: myelin_style
docs.description: use the method from myelin mapping

docs.title: ribbon_roi
docs.description: an roi volume of the cortical ribbon for this hemisphere

docs.title: thickness
docs.description: a metric file of cortical thickness

docs.title: sigma
docs.description: gaussian kernel in mm for weighting voxels within range

docs.title: opt_legacy_bug
docs.description: emulate old v1.2.3 and earlier code that didn't follow a cylinder cutoff

docs.title: myelin_style
docs.description: use the method from myelin mapping

docs.title: opt_subvol_select_subvol
docs.description: select a single subvolume to map: the subvolume number or name
